posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Avatar uses Catholic symbolism and themes as a means to create a sense of spiritual meaning to its universe. However Avatar reduces spirituality down to science and naturalism. Eywa is a 'spirit tree' but is shown to really be the sentient lifeforce of Pandora. 'She' however is not a god but is more of an ancestral governing spirit. The Na'vi aren't particularly special in the ecosystem either, since even the wildlife have the Kuru that allows them to connect to the Na'vi.

Eywa has no ability to stop a bullet from killing someone beyond what nature 'She' controls on Pandora. Eywa has no control of fate. Nor is she in control of the souls of the Na'vi or humans that connect to the spirit tree. They're souls are not transported, merely their memories. In the same way that Qaudritch's memories are given to a Na'vi clone, the memories of Grace Augustine is placed into the Spirit Tree.

This plays into the globalist ideal of removing the supernatural (which is to say the Catholic/Christian supernatural) from society as much as possible. Instead of life after death in the Avatar universe, there is 'life in Eywa' where you essentially get a virtual reality meeting with those who died, but it is not genuine, just relieving a memory.

I like the movie by the way, but it's good to not see Avatar as something profound. It's a sci-fi soap opera and that's okay.

Again I don’t really agree. If you’re actually catholic you should be aware of the philosophy of mind coming from thomism, which would not argue that a bigger and more complex brain = more intelligent. And i’m pretty sure that is standard theology for catholics, thomism does not deny physicalist and biological explanations for consciousness, it simply posits that reflexive self awareness is an immaterial faculty. Thomas aquinas was aware that people can get brain damage and that it augmented their personality, because fundamentally your brain is instrumental in processing and generating consciousness- he just says that the entire complexity of consciousness cannot be reduced to the brain, which is how he distinguishes a sensory or animal soul which is identical to the properties of its current sense data, where as a human brain can abstract and reflexively observe such things. I think you’re being a little too black and white about the interplay between materiality and immateriality in a way that is unlike most catholic thinking, again, thomas himself started with physical accounts of things. I think these movies offer a scientific account but simultaneously present that the human outlook on reality is one track and flawed- they dismiss the spirituality of eywa because they are reductionist and consider the aliens “primitive” and superstitious. In reality the na’vi clearly understand something about eywa the humans mindset blinds them to. Again, jake is a skeptic but still prays to her despite saying he doesn’t even know if anyone’s listening, and eywa answers him. As for blasphemy, read any non protestant literature. Would you call chaucer anti christian because he makes jokes at the expense of religion? No, he’s christian, he’s just having fun. Not that i’m implying cameron or these movies are pro christian, they aren’t, but I don’t think they’re rabidly materialist or anything.

>>179651344
You root for the humans and just accept they've become space nazis because that's what they need to do to survive. Even though it was a silly parody at first it's kind of turned into an interesting little reflection on the nature of humanity; that our morality is more malleable than we perceive and can be dictated more by the need for the preservation of our species than by what we consider to be 'good' by modern standards. A thousand years or so ago you had morality where slavery was accepted and an emperor was considered necessary to govern society. It's fun to imagine what kind of world might exist where we hearken back to a similar code of ethics thousands of years in the future, and helps us develop a better appreciation for our own modern morals born of a life of comfort and plenty.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Angron had laughed, the sound rich and true. ‘Such pretty lies! We fight for the same reasons men have always fought: for land, for resources, for wealth and for bodies to feed into the grinders of industry. We fight to silence anyone that dares draw breath and whisper a different opinion from ours. We fight because the Emperor wants every world in his hands. All he knows is slavery, painted in the inoffensive cloak of compliance. The very notion of freedom is a horror to him.’

‘Traitor,’ Russ hissed.

Angron stood tall, still grinning. ‘Do we give choices to those we slaughter? A true choice? Or do we broadcast that they must throw their weapons into the fires of peace and bow down, faces pushed into the mud like beggars, thanking us for the culture we force upon them? We offer them compliance or we offer them death. How am I a traitor, wolfling? I fight as you fight, as loyal as you are. I do the tyrant’s bidding.’

‘We offer them freedom.’ Russ spoke through clenched teeth, the moon bright in his eyes. ‘You are mutilating your own sons and stealing their minds – now you preach of the Emperor’s tyranny? Are you lost so far in your delusions?’

Angron’s smile faltered, fading away. His face seemed slack, his eyes staring past Russ. Defeat was etched upon features still twitching in pain. ‘You are free, Leman Russ of Fenris, because your freedom matches the Emperor’s will. For each time I wage war against worlds that threaten the Imperium’s advance, there comes another time when I am told to conquer peaceful worlds that wish only to be left alone. I am told to destroy whole civilisations and call it liberation. I am told to demand millions of men and women from these new worlds, to make them take up arms in the Emperor’s hordes, and I am told to call this a tithe, or recruitment, because we are too scared of the truth. We refuse to call it slavery.’

>>179661304
Knowing every victory of diplomacy spares them a potentially costly military campaign, the Ethereals and Water Caste attempt to appeal to every level of Imperial society by emphasizing the many different aspects of the Greater Good. To broaden the appeal of membership in the T'au Empire, the T'au guarantee protection from Imperial retribution to rebellious planetary governors.

They also promise the nobility who control planetary commerce lucrative new sources of income and new technologies in the T'au Empire where they will be free from the Imperium's mandatory tithes and excessive bureaucracy.

The T'au also promise that all Humans will be allowed to enjoy the freedom of religion, so long as the practice of that faith does not conflict with the Greater Good. This is a freedom that is unimaginable on Imperial worlds, where rigid adherence to the Imperial Cult is always enforced.

Perhaps the most alluring aspect of the Greater Good to the common Imperial citizen is the belief that all those who contribute towards it have a meaningful and valued place within T'au society.

In place of the relatively low value the Imperium places on the individual Human life, the T'au seem to believe that everyone has a place, and everyone matters.

A perfect example of this process occurred during the Taros Campaign. When the desert Mining World of Taros was annexed by the T'au Empire, not only did the population of Taros not oppose the move since the world had developed an extremely lucrative trade in strategic ores with the T'au, but the Tarosian Planetary Defence Force actually fought against the Imperial forces sent to reclaim the world for the Emperor as Gue'vesa, shoulder to shoulder with their new T'au allies.

Right, he's just describing one aspect of the defect. The whole problem is that there are those of us who are just high-functioning enough and yet just autistic enough that we don't pay attention to this sort of thing at the critical adolescent period, or if we do, we defer it. What I mean is that there are those of us who are normal enough and have high enough confidence about our general life circumstances that we don't feel any need to justify ourselves, and prefer to keep to ourselves. Then of course life whizzes by and you (almost) never had sex.

I myself remember this time around age 30 when I went to a cousin's wedding and I understood from others that the bride's divorced mother was very emotional, and I also heard that the bride and her mother fought just before the wedding. I realized that the bride's mother was jealous of her daughter for getting married, and what would be a trivial observation for others was a deep revelation for me at the time, because it was the first time in many years that I'd bothered to imagine other people's intimate or sexual relationships. I mentally sealed myself off from that stuff for years.

I've always had intrusive thoughts but they're getting worse. And what started as me knocking on wood every time I had one, now has turned to me knocking on my head with both hands, then knocking on wood. Sometimes this goes on uninterrupted for minutes as I'm trying to get rid of my thoughts (usually I get something scary like a horror flick or something stuck in my mind, and I become convinced that if I don't "exorcise" it it'll come real and haunt me). I've toned down the habit of talking to myself out in public, but it's still there. Sometimes though, when I get too anxious, I start hitting myself, pulling weird grimaces, "silent scream" and have this urge to grab a hammer and smash my brains out, or run at a wall, open my mouth with my hands until I rip off my jaw, things like that. >>179656785
I don't know, I am just figuring it out as I go. The easiest way is to find groups for hobbies that you have. That way you mostly talk about the hobby and can avoid talking about yourself. I learned to be a good listener and ask questions so people will talk about themselves instead of me. From there it is about developing enough trust to feel comfortable with being more vulnerable, which often comes with reciprocating states of vulnerability, most people have shit they are going through, and being able to share that stuff with each other in a sincere and safe way and creating that connection is a big part of feeling human imo. At the end of the day I think most people just want somewhere to belong, and to care about peers and have those peers care about them.

You just have to realize the alternative is basically a sad depressing life of distracting yourself from the soul crushing loneliness with various copes until you die.

posts.com:
what will physical media buyers do when their discs have degraded? The longest you can expect a disc to last is ~25 years when stored in perfect conditions, and less if not. Blu-Rays bought around 2010 will probably stop working some time this decade.

Also, what do you do if you're out traveling or vacationing and want to watch one of your movies? Do you just carry a bunch of movies around with you at all times, or do you buy them a second time digitally?

I used to collect movies when I was young, but digital media just plain has more upsides and downsides when it comes to convenience. And as long as you're buying from a major provider like Google, Amazon, or Apple, you can probably expect 99% of your purchases to remain available for the rest of your life. I can't see myself ever going back to physical, and I'm surprised there are still people clinging on to it.

—No nos arrodillamos tan fácilmente —señaló Ser Arthur Dayne.
—Ser Willem Darry ha huido a Rocadragón con vuestra reina y con el príncipe Viserys. Pensé que habríais embarcado con ellos.
—Ser Willem es un hombre bueno y honesto —dijo Ser Oswell. —Pero no pertenece a la Guardia Real —señaló Ser Gerold—. La Guardia Real no huye.

—No —dijo Ned con voz entristecida—. Esto va a terminar ahora mismo.

Soulful - Adjective;
Literal meaning: Full of soul.

Soulful is floating signifier often used in the context of media consumption. Its original usage was in the context of groovy music of the 70s. In modern usage, family movies and video games for teenagers and young adults from 1990-2010 are often described as soulful. It is related to the transitioning of practical effects to full CGI, the writing of stereotyped- or archetypical characters, and the usage of scenographical techniques emphasizing ambiance.

>>What's so bad about a monster movie having a horrific death? Why must her death have been "deserved"?
>>It's funny to point out how she didn't deserve it but its a bizarre fucking criticism to level at a monster/disaster movie
Nothing at all wrong with horrible deaths, they're usually great. It's an emotional relief or just plain fun to see a "bad guy" get their comeuppance. The reward for their arrogance and behavior is misery. Real life rarely has bad things happening to bad people so it's enjoyable to see it happen in fiction. The way the fat boomer guy died in JW was weak and unsatisfying. Sure it was fun to see him try and pull an Owen before getting his arm bitten off but it was still not as enjoyable as it could have been.

People dying undeserved deaths can be absolutely hilarious if played right. Holocaust movies do it really well. That woman in Schindlers List trying to manage a work site being executed for trying to do her job is great. The hilarity comes from the fast change in tone. The scene goes from workplace dispute to public execution in a few seconds. The surprise and unexpected death is what makes surprise deaths funny. If the Nanny in JW had a more involved role, played the part of an actual character and was suddenly killed unceremoniously in a moment of perceived safety it would have been funny. She was a side-side-side character who everyone knew was dead the moment she was picked up in a dangerous situation. Her death is funny because it's so drawn out, not because she died.

The context of "loser" would be entirely different when the animistic struggles for food shelter and security are no longer relevant. We see this slowly materializing in our cultural zeitgeist with the growth of streamers, their intrinsic value is zero but because we can afford (time) the luxuries of entertainment people have opened new avenues for supporting themselves. We judge someone as being a "loser" through the lens of material wealth and social influence but if neither are relevant criteria how would we judge someone? Do standards revert to grug tier lizard brain stuff like physical appearance? posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: I have unironically watched this film over 50 times
posts.com:
I have been browsing 4chan since 2006, 31 here. In around 2010, I remember being interested in who the dubs guy was from all the "check 'em" memes. I was about 19 then. I remembered torrenting the movie and watching it once alone, and later with a friend. The film always stuck with me. Once every few years, I'd always rewatch it. Eventually I bought it on Blu-Ray.

With every girl I've ever had a serious relationship, I always watch American Psycho with them, at least once. Except, it never is just once. Inevitably, my girlfriends have always ended up choosing to rewatch the film on their own. Without fail. My current girlfriend might be more autistic than me, I've unironically woken up in the morning just to catch her watching American Psycho so many times, I have actually lost count. It's reached the point where saying out lines in sync with the film has become something of a past time of ours. I've always considered it to be the best film ever directed by a woman, truly one of the only works of art made by a woman I can frequently go back to and still find thought provoking. What struck me as funny was my girlfriend telling me I unironically remind her of Patrick Bateman, from my mannerisms and the way I talk and so on. I look nothing like the guy, but I guess I do kind of act like him.

Anyone else have similar experiences with this film? I remember as a child I probably watched Space Jam and The Lion King probably well over 100 times each, but in adult life I don't think I've rewatched any film more than American Psycho.

I feel like maybe the mystique of the film hinges entirely on the fact that while the opulence is present in the film, it's not so harped upon as to become tiresome. This is why so many people watch the film so many times, and still find themselves trying to understand it.

I even tried explaining to my girlfriend that the entire film is about yuppie culture in the 80s, and her first question was of course "what the hell is yuppie culture in the 80s?" I tried to explain how the novel was a commentary on the obsession with appearing more successful and wealthier than others in the 1980s, and how Bateman constantly changing his name is reflective of how people's identities all seemed to meld into one another and make people indistinguishable from one another. She looked at me so confused and seemed to try to force herself to forget I even said it, because I'm sure the film is more enjoyable without such a rigid perspective on what it actually is.

>>179657068
Human height is almost entirely based on nutrition. Genes set our maximum height but whether or not we reach that depends on our diets in childhood and adolescence.
Lots of things can interfere with this; certain diseases, medications, and smoking have all been proven to prematurely end or slow growth.
There's also sex differences. Women grow faster than men but men grow for far longer. Most girls have finished growing by 14 but it's not uncommon for men to keep growing until their mid-20s, but with most growth happening by 16. After that it's only a few mm a year until max height is reached.
The trigger for growth is also complicated. Girls with a high muscle and fat to weight ratio triggers puberty so sporty girls usually are the first to enter adolescence, whereas boys aren't completely understood (although environmental stress can prompt early puberty).
It's assumed that male puberty takes longer because girls are born with all their sex organs and the body just needs to switch them on, whereas boys need to develop our testicles, prostate, adrenal glands, etc further.
Testosterone is our growth hormone and its precursor is cholesterol. We need 10μm cholesterol /kg of bodyweight to grow (as adults), which isn't a lot (there's 200μg in a single egg so a few eggs a day will provide a growing boy with what he needs). Phytosterols can be made into testosterone but it's such an inefficient process that you'd need to eat nuts for every meal. Basically don't raise your son vegan unless you want him to be a manlet.
